title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury. The Group, chaired by the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes, includes representatives from various Treasury offices and bureaus. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury. The Group, chaired by the Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes, includes representatives from different Treasury offices and bureaus to conduct contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions rapidly under various laws. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes a group within the Department of the Treasury to conduct contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions rapidly under various laws, considering factors like vulnerability of the target, effectiveness of sanctions, and costs to the US economy. The Group established by the "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" will review and improve economic sanctions programs, identifying specific and general problems with US economic sanctions policy, and create strategies for enhancement. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes will coordinate the development of US economic sanctions policy with various government agencies and ensure equal sharing of related information. The Group, consisting of various government agencies, must meet at least once a month to ensure equal sharing of information related to US economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes can assign Treasury personnel to assist the Group, and they may consult with experts from academia, research organizations, and the private sector. Additionally, the Group must submit annual reports to Congress. The Group, comprising government agencies, consults with experts from academia, research organizations, and the private sector. They must submit annual reports to Congress detailing contingency planning, identified problems, strategy, and interagency overview. The Group, consisting of government agencies, consults with experts and submits annual reports to Congress detailing contingency planning, identified problems, strategy, interagency coordination, policy expert consultations, and a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment. The assessment may include a classified index and closed briefings for select committees. The comprehensive sanctions impact assessment required by the House and Senate Intelligence Committees includes various research methods to evaluate the impact of economic sanctions on foreign countries and the US economy, as well as behavioral changes in response to the sanctions. The House and Senate Intelligence Committees require a comprehensive assessment of the impact of economic sanctions on foreign countries and the US economy, including behavioral changes in response to the sanctions. The reports will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website. In this section, definitions for "executive agency" and "United States economic sanctions policy" are provided. A new Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group is established to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury.
